author: By Mark Peterson and Michelle Cottle
title: Images From the Capitol Under Siege
description: The usual bustle of lawmakers moving in and out of offices gave way to a horrific scene.
content: On both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue, there is much bustle and churn, as lawmakers, administration officials and staff members — both incoming and outgoing — work toward a smooth transition of power in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Selinger
title: Why Isn’t Kelp Catching On?
description: It’s a superfood and good for the environment. So, what’s the problem?
content: For the past several years, members of the food community and environmentalists alike have looked to kelp, a type of seaweed, as the shiny future of food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Globalfest Moves Online, Showcasing World Music Without Boundaries
description: With 16 bands over four nights, the festival expanded its reach at a time when live music with audiences is in short supply.
content: Minyo Crusaders set an old Japanese song, from a tradition called minyo, to a Nigerian Afrobeat groove. DakhaBrakha, from Ukraine, roved from Eastern European drones and yipping vocals to something like girl-group rock. Aditya Prakash, from Los Angeles, sang a joyful Hindu devotional over upbeat jazz from his ensemble, sharing its melody with a trombone. Rachele Andrioli, from southern Italy, sang a fierce tarantella accompanying herself with a tambourine and electronic loops of a jaw harp and her voice. Hit La Rosa, from Peru, topped the clip-clop beat of cumbia with surreal lyrics, surf-reverbed guitar solos and psychedelic swoops and echoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: New inquiries into the Capitol assault aim to address security lapses before Biden’s inauguration.
description: Government leaders and law enforcement announced new investigations on Friday into the security failures that led to the assault on the Capitol last week, showing how the pressure to secure Washington and other American cities is increasing amid growing threats of violent right-wing unrest ahead of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s inauguration next week.
content: Government leaders and law enforcement announced new investigations on Friday into the security failures that led to the assault on the Capitol last week, showing how the pressure to secure Washington and other American cities is increasing amid growing threats of violent right-wing unrest ahead of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s inauguration next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Uganda’s Leader of 35 Years Is Re-elected Amid Accusations of Vote-Rigging
description: President Yoweri Kaguta Museveni faced his strongest challenge yet from Bobi Wine, a rapper-turned-lawmaker.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — On one side was a 76-year-old grandfather in a sunny yellow shirt and hat, who has held onto power in Uganda for 35 years by doling out patronage to preserve loyalty, while deploying his security forces to intimidate critics and muzzle the media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: One Sentence in Biden Stimulus Plan Reveals His Health Care Approach
description: An increase in subsidies could drive millions to enroll in Obamacare marketplaces, experts say.
content: Tucked into President-elect Biden’s $1.9 trillion stimulus plan is a one-sentence provision that could drive billions in federal subsidies to help people afford to buy health insurance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: The Pariah Post-Presidency
description: Isolated and angry, a diminished President Trump is leaving Washington for an uncertain future.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your wrap-up of the week in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Photos of Trump ally who visited the White House capture notes about martial law.
description: President Trump, isolated and watching the clock count down on his time in the White House, spent some of it on Friday with the C.E.O. of MyPillow, Mike Lindell, who brought some notes with him.
content: President Trump, isolated and watching the clock count down on his time in the White House, spent a few minutes of it on Friday with the C.E.O. of MyPillow, Mike Lindell, who brought some notes with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Biden and Harris introduced members of their White House science team.
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. said on Saturday that he was “always going to lead with science and truth” as he announced top science and technology officials on his White House staff, reaffirming trust in the kind of expert research that the Trump administration often ignored or disdained.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. said on Saturday that he was “always going to lead with science and truth” as he announced top science and technology officials on his White House staff, reaffirming trust in the kind of expert research that the Trump administration often ignored or disdained.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: Is Inflation About to Take Off? That’s the Wrong Question
description: Some analogies can help in assessing the risks: a yo-yo, hungry bears, a sloshing bathtub and a reflating balloon.
content: The warnings that higher inflation lurks around the corner are starting to show up everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: The Noise Upstairs Is Unbearable. How Do I Stop It?
description: You have the right to live in peace — easier said than done in an apartment building where everyone’s cooped up for the winter.
content: Q: I live in a rental building in Harlem and have always worked from home. Since the start of the pandemic, the family directly above me has been home, too, with two young children. Now that winter is here, they never seem to go out. I can hear running, jumping and shouting. Normally, I’d work at the cafe down the street for a few hours, but that’s not an option. I know they must have cabin fever, but so do I. What am I supposed to do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Pentagon Moves to Block Exam of Tortured Guantánamo Prisoner
description: In his final days in office before a new administration takes over, Army Secretary Ryan McCarthy changed a regulation to sidestep court rulings requiring the medical examination.
content: WASHINGTON — In his final days as Secretary of the Army, Ryan D. McCarthy has moved to thwart a federal judge’s order for an independent examination of a mentally ill prisoner at Guantánamo Bay who was previously tortured there, the Justice Department disclosed on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero, Kathleen Gray and Danielle Ivory
title: States Brace for Armed Protests in Wake of U.S. Capitol Attack
description: State officials are activating National Guard troops and closing off Capitol grounds in response to F.B.I. warnings that armed protesters are preparing to act.
content: Bracing for the potential of violent protests in the days leading up to the presidential inauguration on Jan. 20, state officials are calling up National Guard troops, erecting imposing fencing and shutting down Capitol grounds in response to the F.B.I.’s warning that armed protesters could target the capital cities across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin, Judith Levitt and Andrew Rodriguez
title: Banner Headlines for Tumultuous Times
description: For this newspaper, the extraordinary events of the past few months have demanded headlines that take up space.
content: Every once in a while, a news headline calls out for big, bold font.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Salopek
title: Shadows on the Silk Road
description: Finding omens of American decline on a long walk across Asia.
content: YANGON, Myanmar — The looming decline of the United States was revealed to me, five Novembers ago, at a truck stop in Uzbekistan. I was napping after a long day’s hike near the old trading city of Kokand when a brawl exploded. Drunks howled. Fists smacked flesh. Somewhere a window shattered. An anxious waitress poked her head into my curtained dining booth. She wanted to know if I had any sugar in my backpack for a homemade compress to stanch a client’s stab wound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Children’s Screen Time Has Soared in the Pandemic, Alarming Parents and Researchers
description: “There will be a period of epic withdrawal,” warned one addiction specialist, once schools, activities and social life return to normal.
content: The day after New Year’s, John Reichert of Boulder, Colo., had a heated argument with his 14-year-old son, James. “I’ve failed you as a father,” he told the boy despairingly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Atlanta Prosecutor Appears to Move Closer to Trump Inquiry
description: The Fulton County district attorney is weighing an inquiry into possible election interference and is said to be considering hiring an outside counsel.
content: ATLANTA — Prosecutors in Georgia appear increasingly likely to open a criminal investigation of President Trump over his attempts to overturn the results of the state’s 2020 election, an inquiry into offenses that would be beyond his federal pardon power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker
title: Biden Seeks Quick Start With Executive Actions and Aggressive Legislation
description: In an effort to mark a clean break from the Trump era, the president-elect plans to roll out dozens of executive orders in his first 10 days on top of a big stimulus plan and an expansive immigration bill.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., inheriting a collection of crises unlike any in generations, plans to open his administration with dozens of executive directives on top of expansive legislative proposals in a 10-day blitz meant to signal a turning point for a nation reeling from disease, economic turmoil, racial strife and now the aftermath of the assault on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: George Whitmore, Climber Who Vanquished El Capitan, Dies at 89
description: In 1958, he was one of the first people to climb the 2,900-foot-tall sheer granite wall that looms over Yosemite National Park.
content: Early on the morning of Nov. 12, 1958, George Whitmore, Warren Harding and Wayne Merry accomplished something many climbers considered unthinkable: They reached the top of El Capitan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Katie Benner
title: A man with a gun arrested by Capitol Police at a security checkpoint calls it an ‘honest mistake.’
description: The man was arrested on Friday with more than 500 rounds of ammunition in his truck, the police said. He told a reporter he was heading to a security job in Washington and got lost.
content: The U.S. Capitol Police arrested a man at a security checkpoint in Washington on Friday after he flashed what an officer described as an “unauthorized” inauguration credential and a search of his truck found an unregistered handgun and ammunition, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Trump will leave office with his lowest approval rating ever.
description: He also appears to be on track to finish his term with the lowest final approval rating of any modern-day president.
content: Throughout four years of scandals and investigations, President Trump has maintained an approval rating that rarely budged from a 10-point band between 35 and 45 percent. Nothing he could say, do or tweet appeared to dramatically change public opinion of him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Vivian Wang
title: In Hong Kong, a New Party Calls for Stability (and Raises Suspicions)
description: Democracy advocates have called the Bauhinia Party a “Trojan horse” for the Chinese government. But Beijing’s local allies are wary of it, too.
content: BEIJING — They are businessmen, born in mainland China, who serve on top advisory committees to Beijing and profess patriotism for the motherland. One recently traveled to an obscure village in southeastern China to study Xi Jinping’s doctrine for guiding the country to greatness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin
title: Post Trump, Republicans Are Headed for a Bitter Internal Showdown
description: G.O.P. leadership would like to blunt President Trump’s influence over the party. Mr. Trump and his allies want to punish those who have crossed him. A series of clashes looms.
content: As President Trump prepares to leave office with his party in disarray, Republican leaders including Senator Mitch McConnell are maneuvering to thwart his grip on the G.O.P. in future elections, while forces aligned with Mr. Trump are looking to punish Republican lawmakers and governors who have broken with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Last-Minute Rule Seeks Term Limits on Top Career Health Officials
description: The Trump administration wants to mandate job reviews for top government scientists and managers every five years, which could lead to reassignment.
content: WASHINGTON — Top government scientists at the Food and Drug Administration and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention could face reassignment every five years under a new regulation the Trump administration issued Friday evening, a move that surprised health officials across the government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Far-right activist ‘Baked Alaska’ is among the latest Capitol rioters to be arrested.
description: Anthime Joseph Gionet, a far-right media personality nicknamed “Baked Alaska” who is known for livestreaming himself participating in illegal activity, was arrested by the F.B.I. on Friday and accused of illegally storming the Capitol during the attack on the building by President Trump’s supporters last week.
content: Anthime Joseph Gionet, a far-right media personality nicknamed “Baked Alaska” who is known for livestreaming himself participating in illegal activity, was arrested by the F.B.I. on Friday and accused of illegally storming the Capitol during the attack on the building by President Trump’s supporters last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David D. Kirkpatrick, Mike McIntire and Christiaan Triebert
title: Before the Capitol Riot, Calls for Cash and Talk of Revolution
description: A network of far-right agitators across the country spent weeks organizing and raising money for a mass action to overturn President Trump’s election loss.
content: Keith Lee, an Air Force veteran and former police detective, spent the morning of Jan. 6 casing the entrances to the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Andrea Kannapell
title: Countries are bracing for the impact of more contagious virus variants.
description: Alongside the variant discovered in Britain, at least three other troubling variants are spreading less widely: one identified in South Africa and two in Brazil.
content: The more contagious coronavirus variant discovered in Britain has now been detected in more than 50 countries, including Argentina on Saturday, and is believed to be driving surges in at least two.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Facebook will temporarily stop showing ads for gun accessories and military gear.
description: Facebook will temporarily stop showing ads that “promote weapon accessories and protective equipment in the U.S. at least through Jan. 22,” two days after Inauguration Day, according to a statement by the company.
content: Facebook will temporarily stop showing ads that “promote weapon accessories and protective equipment in the U.S. at least through Jan. 22,” two days after Inauguration Day, according to a statement by the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez
title: In Home District, McCarthy Faces Some Backlash From the Right
description: In conservative Bakersfield, Calif., Kevin McCarthy enjoys solid support. But in the days since impeachment, some Republicans now say he has not been loyal enough to President Trump.
content: BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — As Congress prepared to vote on impeachment for a second time, David Bynum reached out to his former boss — Representative Kevin McCarthy of California, the Republican leader in the House.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: As States Expand Access to the Vaccine, Hopes Rise Along With the Confusion
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 16, 2021.
content: “You can imagine it’s almost like a gold rush, but it’s a vaccine rush.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: How British Scientists Found the More Infectious Coronavirus Variant
description: Back in March, researchers decided to routinely record the genetic sequences of the virus they found, giving them a powerful tool for tracking mutations.
content: LONDON — All at once, the coronavirus seemed to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma
title: Nepali Team Says It Has Reached K2 Summit in a Wintertime First
description: The team endured temperatures dropping to 58 degrees below zero during its milestone ascent. “The impossible is made possible!” the leader said.
content: KATHMANDU, Nepal — A Nepali mountain-climbing team said Saturday that it had reached the peak of K2, the world’s second-highest mountain, a feat never before accomplished during winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: U.S. Executes Dustin Higgs for Role in 3 1996 Murders
description: It was the 13th and final scheduled federal execution under President Trump. President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has said he opposes the death penalty.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration executed Dustin J. Higgs early Saturday for his part in a triple murder in 1996, marking the 13th and final scheduled federal execution under President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: She Believed Self-Love Was the Antidote to AIDS
description: Louise Hay’s controversial brand of self-love drew in thousands during the AIDS crisis.
content: In January 1985, six gay men gathered in the self-help author Louise Hay’s living room to discuss a terrifying new disease. At that time fewer than 8,000 cases of AIDS had been reported in the United States. Yet as the deadly epidemic rapidly expanded — within 10 years, over half a million cases would be reported, and over 300,000 deaths — so did Hay’s “Hayride” support group meetings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Could Mitch McConnell Get to Yes?
description: Why the Republican leader should be tempted by the Senate’s opportunity to bar Trump from running for president again.
content: The day before the Capitol Hill riot, Jonathan Last of The Bulwark wrote a dark valediction for Mitch McConnell’s attempts to “manage, contain and outlast Donald Trump.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: A Farewell to the Trump Aesthetic
description: Four years of hard-core branding, soap opera chic and designer trolling are coming to an end. What have we learned? A look back in gilt.
content: Few presidents have exploited the theatrical grandeur of the job quite as enthusiastically or as cynically as Donald Trump, from his proliferating forests of flags to his gilding of the Oval Office. Few have been as strategic about the power of caricature, or had such a complicit wife and court to bolster the spectacle. As a group, they tapped into the dregs of “Dynasty” and “The Bonfire of the Vanities” past that sits nestled in our lizard brains. For four years, we parsed soap opera chic instead of “The West Wing.” The visuals demanded attention, just like the tweets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon prepare us for a busy week to come.
content: ACROSTIC — If I could see the future, I’d feel comfortable making a light reference to the extraordinary cliffhanger of an inauguration we’ve got coming up. I can’t, so I’ll just say that today’s passage is from a very timely source, and ties together two occasions that we will hopefully navigate peacefully in the next few days to come. Team Cox/Rathvon’s choice today is from “The Truths We Hold,” a memoir by the first female Vice President-elect of the United States, Kamala Harris, and it involves an early childhood spent with two parents immersed in civil rights. Although it’s lighthearted, reading the excerpt reminded me of how crucial young people are to progressive movements and the risks really small children take for the future of society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Mike Isaac
title: Inside Twitter’s Decision to Cut Off Trump
description: Jack Dorsey, the chief executive, had reservations about locking the president’s account. But the calls for violence that his tweets provoked were too overwhelming.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Jack Dorsey, Twitter’s chief executive, was working remotely on a private island in French Polynesia frequented by celebrities escaping the paparazzi when a phone call interrupted him on Jan. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Eileen Sullivan and Eric Schmitt
title: Security tightens as law enforcement raises fresh alarms about extremist plots.
description: Law enforcement officials are vetting hundreds of potential airplane passengers and beefing up airport security as officials amplify warnings of violence before the presidential inauguration from extremists emboldened by the Capitol attack last week.
content: Law enforcement officials are vetting hundreds of potential airplane passengers and beefing up airport security as officials amplify warnings of violence before the presidential inauguration from extremists emboldened by the Capitol attack last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Alan Canfora, Who Carried Wounds From Kent State, Dies at 71
description: He devoted his life to pursuing the truth about the tragic events of May 4, 1970, and to keeping them in the public eye.
content: In April 1970, Alan Canfora, a junior at Kent State University in Ohio, was outraged when a friend was killed in the Vietnam War. He was infuriated all the more when President Richard M. Nixon announced an expansion of the war into Cambodia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Ray Taylor
title: A Ray of Hope in a Slimy Southern Cave
description: Residents in the South are coming together to protect their underground ecosystems.
content: One day in 2019, back when crossing state lines to go caving seemed perfectly safe, I drove eight hours from Arkansas to central Tennessee and soon found myself in a muddy belly crawl. Pushing a cumbersome pack in front of me, I used my toes to inch forward. Four younger cavers ahead had exited the tunnel and stood comfortably in a large passage, waiting to continue in the 15-mile-long system.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corporate America Flexes Its Political Muscle
description: Big business breaks with Republicans.
content: It was a long week in the fraught relationship between Washington and corporate America. Dozens of companies announced that they will end political donations to the Republicans who challenged the Electoral College count, or pause giving to all politicians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar, Jack Healy, Mike Baker and Serge F. Kovaleski
title: Capitol Attack Could Fuel Extremist Recruitment For Years, Experts Warn
description: An ideological jumble of far-right extremists and hate groups flourished under President Trump and claimed new energy after the attack on the Capitol. Now they are debating their next moves.
content: Overthrowing the government. Igniting a second Civil War. Banishing racial minorities, immigrants and Jews. Or simply sowing chaos in the streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Germany’s Buchenwald Memorial Urges Visitors to Respect Graves
description: After some visitors went sledding on graves at the former Nazi concentration camp, the foundation running the memorial stepped up security this week.
content: The memorial at the former Buchenwald concentration camp in central Germany stepped up security this week after some visitors went sledding on graves, the latest example of violations that have happened at former Nazi camps in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Recipes to Cook Over a Long Weekend
description: Comforting cakes, stews, cookies and more.
content: Make Kay Chun’s crowd-pleasing riff on a classic, cheesy chicken Parmesan meatballs (above). Or try your hand at dulce de leche chocoflan, pierogis, slow cooker spinach-artichoke stew and more. Find more NYT Cooking recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer and Maggie Haberman
title: A First for an American President, and a First for Donald Trump
description: In the final moments of his presidency, Mr. Trump is confronting an unfamiliar fate: He is being held to account as never before for things he has said.
content: When President Trump faced (and overcame) the gravest crisis of his first campaign, he defended his boasts of sexual assault on the “Access Hollywood” tape as ultimately harmless gabbing. “Locker room talk,” he said, nothing to dwell on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: Go Ahead. Fantasize.
description: Imagining a better future, whether it includes gigantic house parties or just more hugs, helps humans cope with difficult times.
content: Teddy Johnson has a very clear fantasy for what he’s going to do the day the pandemic is “over” — whatever that day might look like, and whenever it may be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: A Step Toward a Post-Merkel World: Her Party Picks a New Leader — Again
description: Armin Laschet, a close ally of Germany’s chancellor, hopes to succeed her when she steps down after fall elections. But that is far from certain.
content: BERLIN — Germany took a first step into a new political era on Saturday, choosing the next leader of Angela Merkel’s conservative party ahead of fall elections that will decide who succeeds her as chancellor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Karan Deep Singh
title: India begins inoculating its 1.3 billion people, starting with health care workers.
description: The vaccine campaign is unfolding in a country with more than 150,000 coronavirus deaths, the world’s third-highest tally.
content: PUNE, India — India on Saturday began one of the most ambitious and complex initiatives in its history: the nationwide rollout of coronavirus vaccines to 1.3 billion people, an undertaking that will stretch from the perilous reaches of the Himalayas to the dense jungles of the country’s southern tip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Lankford Apologizes to Black Voters for Backing Trump’s Election Deceit
description: The Oklahoma senator, who is up for re-election in 2022, said he had not realized his objection to the election results would be seen as a direct attack on the voting rights of people of color.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator James Lankford, Republican of Oklahoma, apologized on Thursday to Black constituents who were offended by his decision to join President Trump in trying to discredit the victory of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., saying he had not realized the effort would be seen as a direct attack on the voting rights of people of color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Pelosi Holds Back Impeachment Article as House Builds Case
description: The speaker called the impeachment of President Trump “urgent,” but did not send the charge to the Senate to prompt the start of a trial, nor commit to when she would do so.
content: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi said on Friday that House impeachment managers were preparing to prosecute President Trump in the Senate, but she refused to offer a timeline for when they would move forward with a never-before-attempted trial of a former president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Magazine
title: The Story of 2020 in 52 Magazine Covers
description: We spent a year documenting our design process. Looking back, we realized we were telling a bigger story, too.
content: Last year, The Times Magazine published a weekly video series called Behind the Cover, which gave readers a behind-the-scenes look at our cover-design process. We’ve just wrapped the season, and we decided to take a look back at all the covers we put out in a profoundly eventful year, shaped by a cascade of world-changing events that changed the way we worked too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott
title: Trump’s ‘Law and Order’: One More Deceptive Tactic Is Exposed
description: The president’s response to the riot at the Capitol underscored the ways he has twisted the phrase “law and order” over the past four years.
content: WASHINGTON — For years, the phrase rolled off his tongue in times of strife, a rallying cry to his predominantly white base.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Kittenplan
title: Figuring It Out: Two Novels About Ice Skating and Adolescence
description: “The Comeback,” by E.L. Shen, and “Ana on the Edge,” by A.J. Sass, put identity on center ice.
content: THE COMEBACKBy E.L. Shen
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Next President Actually Has a Covid Plan
description: America desperately needs a leader who takes the pandemic seriously.
content: It has been almost a year since the coronavirus first emerged in the United States, and it’s still spreading uncontrolled through much of the country. Several mutant variants have emerged — some of them with alarming new properties — and the vaccination campaign that was supposed to finally save the world from this crisis is faltering badly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: Frustrations Boil at Pace of Vaccinations at Long-Term Care Facilities
description: The Trump administration raised hopes of a speedy process for nursing homes and assisted living facilities. Patience is wearing thin.
content: In mid-December, a top Trump administration official floated an enticing possibility: All nursing home residents in the United States could be vaccinated against the coronavirus by Christmas. “It’s really a remarkable, remarkable prospect,” Alex M. Azar II, the secretary of health and human services, declared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Remains to Be Seen, Say
description: Sam Ezersky’s Saturday puzzle takes a toll.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I don’t know if you’re dumbfounded by this tough grid or not, but if you’re here for a little advice and expertise, you’ve come to the right place (not here, exactly, slightly to your right — the comments). Experience, I’ve got, but Sam Ezersky’s exuberant constructions tend to reward flexibility of thought rather than trips around the crossword block. There’s a scant handful of familiar fill in puzzles like this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Marsha Zazula, ‘Metal Matriarch’ of Metallica and Others, Dies at 68
description: She and her husband founded Megaforce Records and introduced the world to heavy metal bands that became major stars.
content: Marsha Zazula, who with her husband, Jonny, founded Megaforce Records at the front end of a heavy metal wave and gave Metallica, Anthrax and other pivotal bands their start, died on Jan. 10 at her home in Clermont, Fla., about 20 miles west of Orlando. She was 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Katie Thomas
title: Biden promises a ‘bold’ federal vaccination campaign.
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., racing against a surge in coronavirus cases and the emergence of a new variant that could worsen the crisis, is planning a vaccination offensive that calls for greatly expanding access to the vaccine while using a wartime law to increase production.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., racing against a surge in coronavirus cases and the emergence of a new variant that could worsen the crisis, is planning a vaccination offensive that calls for greatly expanding access to the vaccine while using a wartime law to increase production.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Sonia Sotomayor will swear in Kamala Harris on Inauguration Day.
description: Justice Sotomayor has sworn in a vice president before.
content: Vice President-elect Kamala Harris will be sworn in on Wednesday by Justice Sonia Sotomayor, a ceremony in which the first woman of color to become vice president will take her oath from the first woman of color to sit on the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meri-Jo Borzilleri
title: Bradie Tennell Wins Her Second U.S. Figure Skating Title
description: Tennell had recently relocated from Colorado to work on recapturing the title she won in 2018.
content: Bradie Tennell uprooted her life last summer, moving from suburban Chicago to Colorado Springs in hopes of finding what she needed to reclaim a national figure skating title. Tennell had won in 2018, then watched Alysa Liu, a sprightly phenom seven years her junior, take the next two championships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Michael S. Schmidt, Luke Broadwater and Adam Goldman
title: Top Lawmakers Not Told of Police Request for Backup Before Riot, Aide and Others Say
description: The rejected request was another key breakdown in the security failure ahead of the violence at the Capitol.
content: WASHINGTON — In the days leading up to the mob attack on the Capitol, congressional security officials never let House and Senate leaders know that the Capitol Police had warned they might need National Guard backup, according to a congressional aide and other people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Forsythe
title: Protesters Who Fled Hong Kong Arrive in U.S., Seeking Asylum
description: The five men fled by boat to Taiwan in July, soon after China imposed Hong Kong’s harsh national security law. This week, they landed in New York.
content: Last July, five young men boarded a recreational boat in a remote harbor in Hong Kong. They passed through waters patrolled by the Chinese authorities and headed east, across the South China Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: How to (Literally) Drive the Coronavirus Away
description: What’s the transmission risk inside a car? An airflow study offers some insight for passengers and drivers alike.
content: Over the past year, as the health authorities have tried to curb the Covid-19 pandemic, researchers have trained their scientific attention on a variety of potentially risky environments: places where large groups of people gather and the novel coronavirus has ample opportunity to spread. They have swabbed surfaces on cruise ships, tracked case numbers in gyms, sampled ventilation units in hospitals, mapped seating arrangements in restaurants and modeled boarding procedures in airplanes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Joanne Rogers, Mister Rogers’s Mrs., Is Dead at 92
description: She worked to preserve the legacy of “Mister Rogers’ Neighborhood,” spreading her husband’s message of kindness. A friend said, “Her presence in my life made me never forget Fred.”
content: Joanne Rogers, who as the gregarious wife of Fred Rogers, the influential creator and host of “Mister Rogers' Neighborhood,” spread his message of kindness after his death in 2003, died on Thursday at her home in Pittsburgh. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: When Biden Becomes … Rooseveltian!
description: Using a crisis to reduce child poverty and make America more truly a land of opportunity.
content: Soon after Franklin Roosevelt was inaugurated in 1933, a visitor assessed the stakes of his New Deal proposal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Double Crossed
description: Tracy Gray and Tom Pepper team up for a wild and woolly Sunday puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — We go way back, almost a decade, with Tracy Gray on Sundays (who often teams up with Jeff Chen). Today I thought she had brought along an ingénue, but I just skip too many weekday puzzles — Tom Pepper’s been around. The two constructors met at a crossword tournament a while ago, kept in touch and now make their collaborative debut, a fun “hidden in plain sight” kind of puzzle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Hill, Arielle Ray and Dahlia Kozlowsky
title: Videos Show How Rioter Was Trampled in Stampede at Capitol
description: Rosanne Boyland died after losing consciousness in the crush of a pro-Trump mob as it surged against the police. Here’s how it happened.
content: Rosanne Boyland, a 34-year-old Trump supporter from Georgia who died during the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, appears to have been killed in a crush of fellow rioters during their attempt to fight through a police line, according to videos reviewed by The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: How to Get the Coronavirus Vaccine in New York City
description: There are multiple websites, disappearing slots and even attempts to game the system. Here’s our guide to what you have to do to get a dose in your arm.
content: It isn’t easy, and it’s probably going to be that way for a while. Right now, there are more eligible people than doses of vaccine. You need diligence and luck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Biden to Elevate Science Adviser to His Cabinet
description: The president-elect will nominate Eric S. Lander to head the Office of Science and Technology Policy, a post left vacant by President Trump for 18 months.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. announced on Friday that he will elevate the role of science in his cabinet as part of an effort to “refresh and reinvigorate our national science and technology strategy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Hill, Arielle Ray and Dahlia Kozlowsky
title: Videos show how a rioter was trampled in the stampede at the Capitol.
description: Rosanne Boyland, a 34-year-old Trump supporter from Georgia who died during the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, appears to have been killed in a crush of fellow rioters during their attempt to fight through a police line, according to videos reviewed by The Times.
content: Rosanne Boyland, a 34-year-old Trump supporter from Georgia who died during the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, appears to have been killed in a crush of fellow rioters during their attempt to fight through a police line, according to videos reviewed by The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer and Maggie Haberman
title: For one of the first times in his life, Trump’s words are having consequences for him.
description: The relationship between President Trump’s words and their consequences has always been fairly straightforward: He says what he wants, and nothing particularly durable tends to happen to him.
content: The relationship between President Trump’s words and their consequences has always been fairly straightforward: He says what he wants, and nothing particularly durable tends to happen to him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Ben Rothenberg
title: With Positive Tests, the Rules Change for Some Players in Australia
description: After some passengers on charter flights tested positive for the coronavirus, 47 players will not be allowed to practice for two weeks.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Organizers of the Australian Open faced a rebellion from players after passengers on two charter flights bringing them to Melbourne tested positive for the coronavirus, prompting orders for everyone aboard to go into quarantine for two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Abend
title: Pixar’s ‘Soul’ Has a Black Hero. In Denmark, a White Actor Dubs the Voice.
description: The casting has fueled a debate about structural racism and fanned anger about stereotyping and prejudice in European-language voice-overs, even when films have main characters of color.
content: COPENHAGEN — Like most of their counterparts around the world, Danish film critics initially greeted “Soul,” Pixar’s first animated feature to focus on Black characters and African-American culture, with rapture, hailing its sensitive, joyful portrayal of a jazz musician on a quest to live a meaningful life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: How to Invest in a Pandemic, Political Crisis and Possible Bubble
description: Despite awful obstacles, the stock market has performed remarkably well. But is it setting itself up for a fall?
content: On the face of it, stocks have behaved impossibly well since they began rebounding last March in response to the Federal Reserve’s emergency intervention in the markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: What could go wrong during the test?
description: Just as with a real launch, technical glitches occur. In an earlier test, known as a wet dress rehearsal, in which the entire countdown was simulated except for igniting the engines, almost everything went well. But in the last few seconds, one of the propellant valves did not close as soon as expected. It turned out that the temperature was a bit lower than predicted, and that made the valve a bit harder to turn. The software has since been adjusted.
content: Just as with a real launch, technical glitches occur. In an earlier test, known as a wet dress rehearsal, in which the entire countdown was simulated except for igniting the engines, almost everything went well. But in the last few seconds, one of the propellant valves did not close as soon as expected. It turned out that the temperature was a bit lower than predicted, and that made the valve a bit harder to turn. The software has since been adjusted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Leatherby and Anjali Singhvi
title: Critical Moments in the Capitol Siege
description: Here is a moment-by-moment timeline of events on Jan. 6, when a mob assaulted the U.S. Capitol.
content: Here is a moment-by-moment timeline of events on Jan. 6, when a mob assaulted the U.S. Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Pelosi: Security Requires ‘Truth and Trust’
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said on Friday that if any House members had acted as accomplices to the attack on the U.S. Capitol, they would face consequences.
content: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said on Friday that if any House members had acted as accomplices to the attack on the U.S. Capitol, they would face consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: Another Hayride
description: Self-help guru Louise Hay’s “Hayrides” drew in thousands during the hopelessness and government neglect of the AIDS crisis.
content: Self-help guru Louise Hay’s “Hayrides” drew in thousands during the hopelessness and government neglect of the AIDS crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 16, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 16, 2021.
content: An article on Friday about a lawsuit against the New York Police Department for its handling of protests last summer described incorrectly the political views of Commissioner Dermot Shea and Chief of Department Terence A. Monahan. They are registered Republicans, but have not said publicly whether they supported President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Call for a Black Migration to the South
description: Readers discuss an excerpt from a book by Charles M. Blow proposing that Black Americans return to the South.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
